Abandoned

Patches break existing systems.  Call for ownership went unanswered.  Open comments on code reviews.

Is xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Service.Manager  used by everyone in the community ? Should we call it directly ?
I know we do a few applications but for most, we first do a ObjectMapper call.

I'm not sure whether it is used by everyone in community, but service-config-manager is the only implementation so far for managing service enable/disable and its port. Ed also suggests to call the service directly instead of objectmapper, https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/50135

Given that this is a global, service level thing, we would never expect to see multiples of this interface produced by multiple daemons, and if that happened, it would arguably be a bug.  I really don't think we should use the mapper here.
I am also in favor of calling directly to srvcfg-manager is here as it reduces cost. I will update this patch.
It can be a util, but I think it's more like a wrapper of service-config-manager service, so I put it in a new file with a new namespace.

What if you use a different application ? 
Before we didn't have this hardcoded.
Keep using GetManagedObjects as there should only be one implementation.
There are both systemd and sdbusplus methods (that are similar) to explicitly encode/decode these paths.  We should be using them.

Unfortunately, service-config-manager does not use sdbusplus to encode path, instead, it only replaces some specific characters. Meaning that it is not in sdbusplus-encodeable format.

https://github.com/openbmc/service-config-manager/blob/ef5ceced0bee522da0fce5c759b9b733298d82bd/src/main.cpp#L135

Probably we have to use this hardcode for now in bmcweb.

Later I will try to use sdbusplus in service-config-manager, then use sdbusplus here.

> Unfortunately, service-config-manager does not use sdbusplus to encode path, instead, it only replaces some specific characters. Meaning that it is not in sdbusplus-encodeable format.
> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/service-config-manager/blob/ef5ceced0bee522da0fce5c759b9b733298d82bd/src/main.cpp#L135
> 
> Probably we have to use this hardcode for now in bmcweb.
> 
> Later I will try to use sdbusplus in service-config-manager, then use sdbusplus here.

Lets do that first, no sense in checking in code that we know is incorrect and will need to be changed.  It looks to my eye like a 5 line patch to fix the config-manager behavior to properly escape things, and we can interlock it with this patch.  If it's really a blocking issue, I can write those 5 lines and push a patch, but it might take me a day or two.

I've submitted a patchset in service-config-manager to encode the object path with sdbusplus. Please help review it.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/q/topic:srvcfg-sdbusplus-encode

I will submit patches in bmcweb later using sdbusplus to encode/decode. These should be merged after the service-config-manager patches merged.

I also created a temporarily patch of bmcweb switching to encode with sdbusplus but keep current code in case my changes not getting merged. If it is not needed, just simply ignore it.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/52562
Can we really ignore the instance here?  If there's more than one instance, should that be an error?

Nope. Some services will have multiple instances, like phosphor-ipmi-net will create instance for each ethernet port, and they are controlled individually in srvcfg-manager. In bmcweb, we need to set the value to all these instances.
Please put this lambda, and the lambdas on lines 41 and 53 in their own method.  FWIW, the later two lambdas are also common, and can use a common method.
nullptr dereference if entry.second.empty() is true.

All of these strings are present in the below struct.  Why are we duplicating them?


nvm, I see why they're duplicated;  If you call the sdbusplus_encode functions, you can convert one of these to the other, and these won't be needed.

This is kept here temporarily. In following patches, these highlighed ones will be removed, all the services names hardcoded here will be in dbus-encoded format to reduce calls to sdbusplus_encode functions.
I haven't reviewed the later patches, but assuming what you say is true, that's ok.  So long as we don't end up duplicating this information in the final patch in the series.
I looked through the rest of the series, where are these ones removed?

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/51753/6/redfish-core/lib/network_protocol.hpp

This one. I have to keep these strings here as finding it in the array brings extra cost.
Looks like this is now fixed.  Resolving.

Wasn't this change already made here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/52521/2

?

Can you take a look at how you stacked your patches and make sure it's what you intended?
Confirmed it is what I intended. Though that patch has a larger id, it should be merged before this patch in this patchset.
Latest patchset looks like it fixed the stacking issue.  Thanks.
Please resolve comments that have been closed
This file doesn't seem to belong to "redfish-core" given it's all DBus related.
It's redfish-related I think as it writes asyncResp. Where do you think is a better place to put this file?

I believe Ed is doing some work to be able to use redifsh-core/ without dbus.

This file can go to the general include? https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/tree/master/include

Just a random comment.

"redfish-core" is a mix of both Dbus-redfish handlers and non-dbus redfish stuff.  The things in these files are specific to managing services, so they belong next to the NetworkProtocol handlers.

I have patches to start separating out dbus more, but I don't think we need to hold up this patch for that.
Said another way, I'm happy to rebase my patches on top of these.
I just learned from my own patch that inplace string literal is better
Needs a better name.  Also, these helper functions have been around a while in a generic form in sdbusplus.  WE should prefer those.
iwyu, at least string, sdbusplus headers are missing,
Done. Btw is there any doc about running iwyu tool in bmcweb?
Take a look at sdbusplus::asio::setProperty you can use it instead. It requires to pass callback, but you can use std::binb_front to avoid code duplication.

IMO, using sdbusplus::asio::setProperty does not save code here as a callback to handle error is still needed. My setProperty here is somewhat similar to the sdbusplus one, except it has its own error handler and hardcoded the service here.

Besides, bmcweb is not using sdbusplus::asio::setProperty currently.
Please use more specific test name. Please take a look at existing test codes.

One concern is that when the passed serviceName is a local string variable, there will be lifetime issue. the underlying variable will be destoryed before the callback is called.

> std::string::operator string_view
> It is the programmer's responsibility to ensure that the resulting string view does not outlive the string.

Though it is not causing any issue in current code as serviceName is `static constexpr const char*`. Shall I add a comment to highlight this?
Why do we need to set both of these?

Setting "Running" is to stop/start the service, while setting "Enabled" is to enable/disable the service startup.

Similar to these 2 systemd commands when disabling one on redfish
systemctl stop my-service && systemctl disable my-service

> Setting "Running" is to stop/start the service, while setting "Enabled" is to enable/disable the service startup.

That doesn't answer the question.  "Enabled" implies that service control manager should start the service, right?  Is this a bug in service manager?

> 
> Similar to these 2 systemd commands when disabling one on redfish
> systemctl stop my-service && systemctl disable my-service

ACK

> That doesn't answer the question.  "Enabled" implies that service control manager should start the service, right?  Is this a bug in service manager?

I think it was some design issue. "Enabled" means start the serivice on startup, "Running" means the current status of the service. It is mapped to the systemd control properties, not Redfish property.
should we just return a return code here?  Different usages will need to set different jsonPointers here
It's async function, I think having an extra argument will be better here. Ack.
This function is too complex to be contained entirely in a lambda.  Please move the logic to a normal method.

Please follow the provision we do elsewhere (similar to what asio does) where we return error codes.  What you've done here is javascript style callbacks, which don't play nicely with non-reference counted callbacks
Please make this a normal method.
This is still too complex to be a lambda.  Please make it a normal function.
is this series still being worked?
string_view is generally not passed as const.
Do we really need to pull in all Managed objects just to get a single entry?  Given that we know the name and the expected path, can we just query Properties.GetAll directly?
Please make this lambda its own method.

I fixed this patchset, and I see a couple functional problems with it.

1. Service-config-manager is now required, otherwise PACTCHING a enabled change returns an internal error.
2. On systems without the services listed, the services still show up in NetworkProtocol.
Can you add BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR with the error code (ec) to log internal errors, which will help with debugging.
internalError already logs to BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR automatically.  Why do we need both?

Internal doesn't log EC. EC will help in debugging
 https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/63895
That hasn't been my experience, but it's not imporant enough for me to argue the point.

TL; DR, As written, this patch series will break any platform that isn't ibm/intel.  I'm looking for someone to own them going forward.

Now that these are rebased, and at least do what they intend, is there anyone willing to take on getting this feature finished?  If nobody volunteers by 2/23/24 (two weeks), I will abandon the series so the review series falls off the review list.

The things remaining are we need to make a decision about either this patch is making service-config-manager optional, or service-config-manager is going to be included as a default required daemon in the build.

To become a default, the check check below in service-config-manager needs removed (and relevant startup conditions handled properly).

https://github.com/openbmc/service-config-manager/blob/d8effd63e885cb755aa44665d833b20f187c0e53/src/main.cpp#L336

We can't have a daemon that is "required" be able to hold up all of startup if some other daemon fails, and there's no way bmcweb takes a hard dependency on the full startup being complete, given that bmcweb is used for failure analysis.  Looking at the code, it's mostly just a matter of the daemon adding handling for the UnitNew signals in /org/freedesktop/systemd1

Arguably it needs to do that anyway, because any sort of other manager might install/start a new service that would get missed by this app.
 Also, given that the listed maintainer (Appu) hasn't responded upstream in O(months) to trivial changes, I suspect we'll need to get more maintainers added.
 https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/service-config-manager/+/67897

Alternatively, if we device that service-config-manager shouldn't be required, we can change the bmcweb flow to something like:

1. Go to the systemd api, determine service status
(note, this is already how bmcweb master works)
2. If the service is running, and we've requested a change, THEN go to service-config-manager

The result is that for service status, service-config-manager is not required.  For service CHANGES, we can attempt to go to service-config-manager, and return some sort of NOT SUPPORTED error back to the user if it doesn't exist.


I would really have liked it if the authors had at least acknowledged that this patch broke other platforms BEFORE I spent a ton of time rebasing them, fixing the coding errors, loading them on my system, and testing the behavior.  I understand that people are busy, and these things are non trivial, but knowingly breaking behavior for working platforms is frankly unacceptable.  If each patch were allowed to break other people, every platform maintainer would have to review every patch, and we'd never get anything done.

To anyone watching, this change makes Service Config Manager a hard requirement on all systems, but that service is not the default.  That is why this patch series is stuck.  I only see Service Config Manager explicitly added to meta-ibm and meta-amd, so this would break all other platforms, and cause them to return Port: null, ServiceEnabled: false for all protocols.

The result is obviously unacceptable, so we either need to make srvcfg-manager enabled on all platforms, or have some fallback, to where we check systemd first, and if systemd reports not running THEN we check srvcfg-manager to see if it's in the process of being started.
Ack. Thank you for the summary.

FWIW, I rebased these patches, and fixed up the coding errors hoping I could land them, but we need to have a bigger discussion around service config manager.

As-is, if I enable service config manager, it gets stuck waiting for the system to start, and bmcweb reports all services as unavailable (which isn't true).  That doesn't seem like a great failure mode.  We might need to look into that on the service config manager side before this can be enabled everywhere.
We are okay with bmcweb waiting on service config manager to come up. 😬 I know not everyone is.

> We are okay with bmcweb waiting on service config manager to come up.

it's more than that, service config manager doesn't come up until the system has passed the "Started" phase, but bmcweb is part of the started phase, so there's a design problem that needs solved somewhere, otherwise services that are up report that they're not which is a race that users might not see in practice on a functional system.
